title: My New Orleans
name: My New Orleans
description:
A Map by Kylebravo

Prior to Hurricane Katrina, I was living in New Orleans, and I was working on making an all inclusive map of the city with points of interest that were of significance to ME, rather than what you'd find on a typical tourist map. Well, that map got flooded in the storm, and then I heard about platial on NPR and thought, hey, maybe I can just make my map there. So, this is MY New Orleans. It's about what makes the city important and meaningful to me as an individual who lived there, walked my dog down the sidewalks, rode my bike through the streets, drove my truck through the maze of traffic, and spent much time in and out of the many crumbling yet beautiful buildings throughout the city. This is why I love New Orleans. By the way, I have like 200 sites I want to put into this map, but, obviously, that will take a good bit of time, so it may take me awhile to get a decent amount of content in here.

properties.name: Abandoned Castle
properties.description: Posted by Kylebravo2256 N. Claiborne, New Orleans, LAThis place is so huge. It\'s like an abandoned castle. I don\'t know what it used to be, probably some kind of factory or something. But now it\'s just overgrown with weeds and boarded up. I wish it was mine. Maybe one day I\'ll work up the guts to sneak into it. of course, now, with Katrina, I\'m sure there will be many more abandoned "castles" out there, but this one always caught my eye from the first time I saw it.

properties.name: Abandoned Church
properties.description: Posted by Kylebravo700 St. Ferdinand, New Orleans, LAThis old catholic church isn\'t in use anymore. It\'s got this sort of creepy, lonely, deserted, feeling about it. Like it would be haunted by a pale and sad creepy little kid. It’s simultaneously beautiful and sad. There\'s a statue of Mary in the yard next to it that\'s equally as creepy. I’m not sure how long this church has been closed up and unused, but there are likely to be more churches that close their doors post-Katrina, and the building s will be left to decay and fall into disrepair.

properties.name: Alvar St. Library
properties.description: Posted by Kylebravo913 Alvar St., New Orleans, LAThe closest library to where I live. It\'s really small. I\'ve only been there once to look for tax forms, but they didn\'t have them.

properties.name: Bywater Post Office
properties.description: Posted by Kylebravo1521 Poland, New Orleans, LAThis post office is so close to our house I bet you could stand on our patio and hit it with a rock if you could throw really hard. How cool is it that there\'s a post office like 50 yards from my house? Of course, it’s been closed since Katrina. I think it flooede pretty bad and they totally gutted it. I wonder how much mail got destroyed from getting flooded in there. I heard a rumor that they were going to reopen in. I haven’t seen any evidence yet.

properties.name: Captain Sal's
properties.description: Posted by Kylebravo3168 St. Claude, New Orleans, LAFor some reason the only kind of food you can get in our neighborhood is either poboys or chinese food. Now poboys and chinese certainly have their place – I love them both – but sometimes you just want some hummus, or pizza, or something! Every time my Dad comes in town we always get poboys here. I\'m not sure how it came to be the one and only place we get poboys out of the plethora of poboy shops around here. But for whatever reason, it’s become a staple every time my parents visit. They pile on a shit-ton of shrimp or oysters or whatever you get, which is good, but they don\'t put on pickles, which is bad.

properties.name: Channel Zero Video
properties.description: Posted by Kylebravo800 Louisa, New Orleans, LASmall, independent video store in the Bywater. It\'s not as good as the independent video store we had when we lived in Richmond, nor is it as good as the free media center I could get movies from when I went to UNC in Chapel Hill, but hey, I guess some towns probably don\'t have any small, independent video stores, so I shouldn\'t complain. Decent selection of both popular and obscure movies. But last time I road by this place it didn’t seem to be open yet. Does anyone know if it’s open or if it’s going to open back up?

properties.name: Hot Iron Press
properties.description: Posted by Kylebravo1420 Kentucky St., New Orleans, LA 70117This is where I live and work. We got 5.5. feet of flooding during Katrina which pretty much wiped out everything in our studio. We\'ve done a good bit of work, cleaned up, and gotten it basically habitable again, but we still have a lot to do - fix the roof, paint, get electricity, get a new AC unit, etc.

properties.name: Iron Rail and Plan B Community Bike Project
properties.description: Posted by Kylebravo511 Marigny St., New orleans, LAIron Rail is a collectively run anarchist bookstore, with books, zines, a zine library, and occasional events. Plan B is a collectively run, nonprofit bike repair shop where you can use their tools for free, learn to fix your bike, or get spare parts for cheap. Very friendly, wonderful people who run it. These 2 places played a huge role in my decision to move to New Orleans in the first place. I figured, if there\'s such cool people doing such cool projects in such a cool city, then I probably would like it there!

properties.name: My House Center For Learning
properties.description: Posted by Kylebravo2010 Peniston, New Orleans, LABesides running Hot Iron Press, this is also where I worked prior to Katrina. It\'s a nonprofit that does many different things, but what I did was work as an art instructor for kids from the neighborhood (pre-k through 6th grade). During the school year they have an after school program for the kids with art, science, music, etc, and during the summer they have an all day camp. It was a never-dull experience dealing with these kids and trying to get them pumped about art. In spite of, and sometimes because of, their bad-ass attitudes and constant energy, I really grew to love the spunk and irreverence of the youth of New Orleans. I feel like my experience with them gave me an awesome opportunity to get to know and better understand New Orleans through the eyes of its children. Immediately after the storm they weighed heavily on my mind. What happened to them? Are they ok? Will I ever see any of them again? I\'ve yet to see or hear about a single one of them.

properties.name: The Green Project
properties.description: Posted by Kylebravo2831 Marais Street, New Orleans, LAThis place is this big warehouse where they sell all these old, salvaged materials from buildings that have been torn down, and other stuff that otherwise would be thrown out, but still is in good enough condition to be reused. You can get really cool, old stuff here for very cheap. Good for the wallet, good for the environment, good for destroying Home Depot and Lowes, and it helps preserve the history of objects and architecture from the city\'s past.

properties.name: “Don't Go Any Further”
properties.description: Posted by Kylebravo   4300 St. Claude, New Orleans, LA One thing I love about New Orleans is how all over the city the street names are cemented into the sidewalks in tile. At this spot there\'s tiles in the sidewalk that say “DON\'T GO ANY FURTHER.” Why is this here? Why can\'t we go any further? Needless to say, no one heeds this mysterious warning. I think most people probably have never even noticed it.
